reviewText: I love Christmas fantasy.  A child at heart this one did not quite do it for me.  I think there are so many more movies that have developed the stories better that I have become spoiled. reviewText: While I do see the other reviewers' points, I watched these when I was little! These cartoons are from the 30's and 40's so of course there using the veiws that were held in that TIME period, so if you are offended easily I suggest you don't watch. However I found Santy's Suprise to be cute. All the different children working together...what's so wrong with that? These used to be my grandmother's cartoons that she bought for me when they were released on VHS. My favorites were always Christmas comes but once a year, Somewhere in dreamland, and Hectors hectic life.

reviewText: [Later: After several more viewings, I'm still laughing at details I'd missed: each little film bristles with non-stop action and humor--much of it too subtle or quick to be caught the first time around--and that's, to quote the title of one such gem, "Snow Foolin."  The humor, moreover, is consistent with the emphasis throughout on "making the most of what you already have"--in other words,  on "inventiveness" (in short supply compared to the "creativity" claimed these days on every child's behalf).  Kids love "transformer" toys, and this collection offers them in abundance--a continual morphing of the mundane into the magical (e.g. when a choral-director "hen" instructs all of us in the theater to follow the bouncing ball in the singing of "Jingle Bells," then discovers she has no ball.  No problem; she quickly produces an unhatched egg--calling it a "chicken's suit"--and hatches arguably the most joyous 'Jingle Bells" on film.  And when a coffee-serving turtle asks a shivering little bird why she didn't fly to Florida, she answers: "At these prices, who can afford it?"  Yes, the films are educational, spiritual, and funny!}As a fan of movies, musician, teacher, and a former collector of films--in 16mm and  super-8 format, including Castle Films and classic movies from the Blackhawk Film Company in Davenport, Iowa--I'm somewhat shocked, dismayed, and even offended by some of the negative reviews and cursory, indifferent dismissals of this treasury of Christmas films, several of which were drawn by the master himself, the legendary Max Fleischer.  Certainly the great director Martin Scorsese (Hugo [HD]) would share my appreciation of the quality and even "timeless" artistry of these short films, which in many ways eclipse the technical wizardry of modern-day cinematic spectacles. Rather than offering the child an alternative, "virtual" reality in which all of the imagining is done for the passive, helpless spectator, these films help children to "exercise" their imagination, while provoking questions about the meaning of Jesus, Santa, Rudolph and the rest of the eclectic Christmas "cast."  They comprise nine wonderful and wondrous "little" movies that reach out to children and adults alike, awakening eyes--and hearts--to the little but powerful pleasures of this magical holiday season celebrating the birth of a little baby in a lowly little stable.  No, these are not the "thrill rides" of today's cinematic spectacles, in which children are sitting alongside Santa for the duration of the ride,  getting whip-lashed by overwhelming visuals with "shock editing" while simultaneously being overwhelmed by the floor-shaking vibrations of the thunderous Dolby surround-sound system. Still, what's left after the ride is over?  I don't even recall a child leaving the theater singing a song from the movie, as was so often the case in the "Golden Age" of filmmaking during which these "little" movies appeared..  As trivial as these cartoons may seem to modern viewers, they may offer more to the child than numerous big blockbuster spectacles that constantly seek our time and money.  Even in the midst of joy and pain, each little film offers "teachable moments."First, the narratives are "exemplary" throughout, despite the protests of some of the "political-correctness police" (are we really so morally superior to those who lived before 1960?).  The emphasis in these short films, some indisputably "miniature masterpieces," is on service, gratefulness, making the most of what you have--in other words, on the the true meaning of Christmas, or as St. Paul writes, on "faith, hope and charity--and the greatest of these is charity" (the closest approximation in English to "unconditional love,' or the gift of "grace," as embodied in the "little" story of the birth of the Christ child in a little stable).  In the first cartoon (note the immediate example of "inventiveness" in the "rump cushions" devised by the leap-frogging frisky young reindeer), Rudolph the Red-Nosed Reindeer writes an urgent letter of explanation to his parents; in the last, hungry children reach out to console their distraught and destitute mother before going to their beds, where at least they can receive consolation by dreaming about eating--upon closer examination this little "dream film" is like one of the powerful poems of protest that the poet-prophet William Blake wrote (in child's language) to expose and denounce the exploitation of children!  Now we're getting to the meaning of Christmas, unpleasant as it may be for some to deal with.Besides service, humility, and gratefulness, the films stress the magic of movies that live up to Orson Welles' definition of film as a "ribbon of dreams," leading us to imagine what we "can" be.  By comparison, the cinematic "spectacles" of today often do the imagining "for" the spectator.  The child becomes the manipulated, helpless subject of overwhelming visuals and overpowering sound effects--all offering a surrogate experience that's more "virtual" than real.  Nothing of value, or self-fortification, is left upon impressionable young viewers once they leave the theater and enter the "real" word.  Indeed a powerful impact is felt, but how does it exercise the child's imagination or impart "knowledge"?  By contrast, each of these films imparts a song, plants an idea. provokes a question.  And even in films with violence, there's no danger of its producing psychotic states within unstable spectators, who soon can no longer distinguish between their virtual reality and that of most sane people.Equally important is the sheer visual artistry of the animated cartoons--most of it by the legendary master, Max Fleischer.  Notice the detail, the movement, the frames--all drawn by hand.  Nothing like it occurs today.  Perhaps our needs for escape are too great, our dependence on technology so total that the separation between technology and artistic content no longer applies--the technology "is" the experience--and unfortunately the meaning as well.  The result is an experience that finally adds up to less than that supplied by any single one of the sparkling 9 gems in this collection.Finally, each of these little pieces owes much of its life, charm, and joy to it music.  It's not the "usual" movie music of creating and intensifying a "mood" but a continually joyous expression of emotion, of feelings inaccessible to regular language.  (Except for the infectious "Jingle Bells" cartoon, in which we see a bouncing ball--or, rather, "egg"-- "ring the bell" on every syllable of that timeless holiday classic.)  Music underscores the meaning of each film,--the expression of an understanding, or non-verbal meaning, too overflowing for words.  As a gift that requires nothing more than itself, music "is" the meaning of each of the 9  vignettes.  Music, like life, is a temporal art.  It marks the time that we live on this earth, trying to make sense of the life that's in store or the time that remains for each of us.  These little films dismiss the cliches and platitudes, suggesting instead that perhaps the best we can hope for is to listen, to sing and dance, and to dream--and to do whatever we can to ensure that those who follow us may do the same.  It's all so simple, and yet, as we may discover in these hectic digital days, extremely difficult.  But why not take up the challenge by trying to find meaning, pleasure, joy--whether just one or all three--in one of these lyrical pieces of visual poetry--little movies that once could help Americans affirm the beauty of life, love and family, even after the horrors of two world wars.Addendum: I notice that some reviewers have a difficult time separating the movie "itself" from this particular "edition" of it.  Before the current favorite Christmas film, Frank Capra'sIt's A Wonderful Life (Two-Disc Collector's Set)was rediscovered, taken out of the public domain, and "restored" to its original pristine condition, it had been subjected to cheap transfers that, even in DVD format, were many generations removed from the original master print.  As a result, the present-day viewer saw and heard, in place of the crisp images and often gripping soundtrack of the original 1946 movie, a fuzzy, unfocused, distorted, nearly unwatchable facsimile that barely resembled what viewers saw and experienced upon seeing the original film with Jimmy Stewart and Donna Reed.  Even a 1946 viewer would have asked for their money back (all 25 cents).  If you wish, point out the inadequacies of the "messenger"--i.e. the inferior edition or print or transfer you received--but try not to trash the "message": the quality of the original drawing, writing, narration and music as well as the experience of the 1940s' viewer experiencing all of that creative expression on the big screen at the Rialto or Bijou theater (in Rockford, Illinois, it was the Coronado Theater that had the biggest and brightest screen).[Addenda:  I continue to be perplexed by the charges of the (right-wing? left-wing?) "thought police."  Where is any of the  films "racist"?  Where are they "lewd"?  Who's making these comments?  You're forcing me to watch these films too many times, straining each time to find anything the least bit objectionable.  Aha! I caught a glimpse of a black child shining shoes and of the underwear of a female child--each for a fractional second.  I wonder if you--like I--worked shining shoes for a living (O.K., I'll admit that Santa never came to my shoe stand.)  Were the rags worn by these unfortunate cartoon characters really  "prurient" compared to the clothing modeled by Honey Boo Boo and the precocious beauty contestants in "Princesses and Tiaras."  Or is Max Fleischer the problem, the brilliant animator whom the moral squad has condemned for his "Betty Boop" series?  But she's not to be seen in this collection.  Nor is Holden Caulfield nor Huckleberry Finn nor Quentin Tarantino ("Django Unchained) nor Edna Ferber ("Showboat")--to mention a few characters and stories forbidden by certain "child protection groups. In their zeal to expunge anything they find objectionable, these PTA police, these prideful Puritans, merely sow and implant the venomous seeds of their own bigotry. Nothing could be more counterproductive. I only wish I could say to them: "Aim your sites at the NRA--but first take note that not a single gun, weapon or corpse (the latter suddenly ubiquitous in television crime series) appears in this entire collection.  Above all, challenge your child to locate and rehearse examples of the continual "Inventiveness," or resourcefulness, in each of these instructive tales.  It could well serve as an education for both of you.)]
summary: (1944 Rudolph) Morphing the mundane into the magical while celebrating the meaning of Christmas!
Title: N/A

reviewText: What every other one star said. Heavy racial stereotypes. My husband is a regionally well known, published historian, and he did not find anything redeeming from an historical perspective.They are pretty old animation sequences, but I don't have a problem with the "quality" per se of the animation as a general viewer. But there is no way my child is watching these for entertainment and we are calling it a teaching moment when my alternative is to turn it off and teach her that is the appropriate response. Its free on Netflix, BTW.  I would have been pretty upset if we had paid to rent it.Remember uncle Remus? That kind of thing. Disney put that in the vault and won't let it out for a good reason. Romanticizing derogatory stereotypes or feeling nostalgic about entertainment with racist overtones is inappropriate. But if you must, please do not indelibly etch these images into your child's consciousness.
summary: I turned it off because of my kid
